title: R44682
content: The report provides tenure data for 16 staff position titles typically used in House Member offices, offering insights on congressional job tenure from various perspectives. The positions include Administrative Director, Casework Supervisor, Caseworker, and Chief of Staff. The most recent publicly available House staff compensation report in 2010 relied on self-reported survey data for congressional staff tenure information. This report is based on official House pay reports, providing reliable and complete data for analyzing tenure in various staff positions. The tenure information in this report is based on official House pay reports from 2006 to 2016, providing data on staff tenure in House Member offices over time. The data includes all staff with at least one week's service on March 31 each year, with employment pay dates from October 2, 2000, to March 24 annually. While this method may offer more comprehensive findings than surveys, there are challenges that could impact the interpretation of the data. The tenure information in this report, based on official House pay reports from 2006 to 2016, may understate actual staff time in positions due to data limitations. Some individuals may have unknown service lengths before October 2, 2000, not captured in the data. The data last capture those employed in House Members' personal offices as of March 31, 2016. The data in this report represent an individual's consecutive time spent working in a specific position in a House Member's personal office. It does not capture overall time worked in a House office or across a congressional career. Job title changes are recorded separately, and if a person stops working for the House, their tenure in the previous position ends. No aggregate measure of individual congressional career length is provided in the report. The Appendix provides the number of related titles included for each job title for which tenure data are provided. Aggregation of tenure by job title rests on the assumption that staff with the same or similar title carry out the same or similar tasks. Given the wide discretion congressional employing authorities have in setting the terms and conditions of employment, there may be differences in the duties of similarly titled staff that could have effects on the interpretation of their time in a particular position. The report provides insight into the tenure of congressional staff members in various positions since 2006. It includes data on job titles, average and median years of service, and trends in staff tenure. The location of congressional employment and its impact on staff retention is unknown. Tables in the report offer detailed information on individual job titles and tenure data for selected positions. The report analyzes congressional staff tenure from 2006 to 2016, with tables detailing job titles and tenure data. The average and median tenure lengths are discussed as measures of central tendency, highlighting how outliers can skew the average. The report discusses congressional staff tenure from 2006 to 2016, highlighting the limitations in generalizations due to the lack of demographic information. The median is presented as a central tendency measure less affected by extreme observations. Between 2006 and 2016, staff tenure in House Member offices has increased by six months or more for some positions, while remaining unchanged for others. Pay is a factor influencing how long individuals stay in their roles, with lower-paying positions typically having shorter tenures. Senior positions requiring congressional or professional experience tend to have longer tenures. Job titles in congressional offices vary widely. Between October 2000 and March 2016, House and Senate pay data provided 13,271 unique titles under which staff received pay, categorized into 33 job titles used in CRS Reports about Member or committee offices. Job titles in congressional offices vary widely, with some specific to Member or committee offices, reflecting factors specific to particular offices. Some congressional offices use various job titles to indicate different levels of seniority or specific roles, such as Administrative Director or Caseworker. Titles may also be modified by location, policy area, party affiliation, or committee subdivision. Some congressional offices use different job titles to show seniority or specific roles. The titles in this report were used by most House Members' offices, with variations included for additional offices and staff.
